learnings.title: Strategic Networking and Mapping
learnings.bodyMd:
# Strategic Networking and Mapping

## Overview
Map your relationship capital: who you know, strength of ties, and gaps aligned to goals.

## Key Concepts
- Map: mentors, peers, partners, communities.
- Tie strength: frequency, reciprocity, trust.
- Portfolio: diversify roles and domains.

## Examples
- Network map by role and geography.
- Quarterly outreach plan to rebalance ties.

## Common Pitfalls
- Only networking when you need something.
- Homogeneous networks that limit perspective.

## Summary
Treat relationships as long‑term assets. Map intentionally and invest consistently across diverse ties.

learnings.title: Reciprocity and Being Useful
learnings.bodyMd:
# Reciprocity and Being Useful

## Overview
Offer value first: introductions, insights, and small favors that compound goodwill.

## Key Concepts
- Give‑to‑give, not quid‑pro‑quo.
- Specific, timely, and relevant help.
- Memory of favors builds trust.

## Examples
- Share a concise resource tailored to their goal.
- Introduce peers with a clear double‑opt intro.

## Common Pitfalls
- Generic mass outreach.
- Favors with strings attached.

## Summary
Be helpful without expectation. Small, targeted acts build strong, resilient ties over time.

learnings.title: Mentorship, Sponsorship, and Communities
learnings.bodyMd:
# Mentorship, Sponsorship, and Communities

## Overview
Mix mentorship (guidance), sponsorship (advocacy), and community engagement to multiply opportunities.

## Key Concepts
- Mentors: skill growth and perspective.
- Sponsors: put their reputation on the line for you.
- Communities: learning, visibility, serendipity.

## Examples
- Quarterly mentor/sponsor check‑ins with goals.
- Contribute talks or posts to relevant communities.

## Common Pitfalls
- Expecting mentorship to be therapy.
- Neglecting to give back to communities.

## Summary
Cultivate mentors and sponsors intentionally and contribute to communities to expand your surface area of luck.

learnings.title: Cadence, Check‑Ins, and Serendipity
learnings.bodyMd:
# Cadence, Check‑Ins, and Serendipity

## Overview
Lightweight, periodic touchpoints keep relationships warm and open space for serendipity.

## Key Concepts
- Touchpoint cadence: monthly/quarterly depending on tie strength.
- Lightweight updates and asks.
- Randomized outreach to avoid clusters.

## Examples
- Monthly list to ping with a note or share.
- Rotate through contacts using reminders.

## Common Pitfalls
- Only reaching out with asks.
- Overloading contacts with long updates.

## Summary
Keep it brief and regular. Share value or check in with no ask to maintain goodwill and awareness.

learnings.title: Measuring and Nurturing Relationship Capital
learnings.bodyMd:
# Measuring and Nurturing Relationship Capital

## Overview
Track the health of key relationships and invest where it matters most.

## Key Concepts
- Simple health scores: frequency × usefulness × trust.
- Pipeline view: new, active, dormant.
- Small bets: coffees, intros, shared projects.

## Examples
- Quarterly review of top 20 relationships.
- Revive dormant ties with tailored notes.

## Common Pitfalls
- Letting strong ties decay unnoticed.
- Over‑engineering metrics vs. human connection.

## Summary
Use lightweight tracking to focus attention. Take small, consistent actions to keep relationships healthy and mutual.
